question: I notice waves look different sometimes - some are chaotic and others more uniform. What's the difference between seas and swells?
generated_answer: In summary, seas are short-period, irregular waves generated by local winds, while swells are long-period, more uniform waves produced by distant storms.
ground_truth_answer: Seas are short-crested, irregular waves that are still being created by winds or are very close to their generation area. Swells, on the other hand, have moved far from where they were generated and form longer, smoother, more uniform waves because wave energy becomes more organized as it travels long distances.
